text: hey everybody thomas joseph here with
another thanksgiving conundrum a lot of
you have been asking about how to fix
lumpy gravy if your gravy turns out like
this where there are big lumps of flour
if you didn't thicken properly and i'm
going to show you today how to make the
perfect gravy our gravy 101 and then if
in fact you do end up with a lumpy gravy
how to fix it
so I have a roasting pan here that we've
roasted our Thanksgiving turkey in and
what you want to do is you want to
strain the juices and the fat through a
fat separator and what a fat separator
does is the fat floats to the top and
the juices all of the wonderful turkey
juices sink to the bottom and let that
sit for a while and now place the
roasting pan over heat about a
medium-high heat and I'm going to
deglaze with one cup of giblets off now
what you want to do here is make sure
that you scrape up all of those
wonderful brown bits on the bottom of
the pan because that's really where all
of the flavor is and then bring this
mixture to a boil and while this is
coming up to a boil take a glass jar
with a tight-fitting lid or any type of
container with a tight-fitting lid and I
have instant flour here and what's
really great about instant flour is it
dissolves so easily so one tablespoon
and I'm going to take about two cups of
the giblet stock that we have and add it
right to this jar now a giblet stock is
simply the giblets from the turkey a
little bit of water onion bay leaf
sometimes peppercorns also the neck of
the turkey and you just need to simmer
that together until it really has a nice
old dynamic flavor so tighten up the jar
and give this a good shake and you can
see that there are no lumps in the jar
this instant flour also known as Wondra
you can find it in any supermarket
really does dissolve very quickly and
even
so the pan is nice and deglaze I'm going
to add our flour stock mixture right
into the pan and you just want to stir
this together and bring this mixture up
to a boil and reduce your gravy until
it's nice and thick so the gravy is nice
and thick you can see when you stir in
the pan that a line remains and that's
how you know that the gravy is thick
enough so I'm going to add the defatted
juices that I have from the turkey just
the juices from the turkey with that
wonderful dark color stop right when you
get to the fat and discard all of the
fat and gently stir this into your gravy
season with a little bit of salt and
some freshly ground pepper give this a
strain through a nice fine mesh sieve
and there you have it gravy 101 if you
do have a lumpy gravy there is a very
easy way to fix it you don't have to
start over so in the roasting pan here
I'm going to give it a little bit of a
whisk give your gravy a little bit of
whisk and what it does is it breaks up
any of the flour pockets that remains
simply take your gravy and strain it
through a fine mesh sieve to get out any
of those giant lumps of flour if your
gravy seems to be a little too thin
there is a way to thicken it now as well
so I'm going to pour this into a pot you
could also do this in the roasting pan
if you'd like put it on medium heat and
similar to what we have done with the
turkey 101 gravy is in a jar with a
tight-fitting lid take about 2 cups of
giblet stock and again another
tablespoon of that fine fine instant
flour so our gravy is nice and hot I'm
going to take a little bit of our
instant flour and giblet stock mixture
and I'm going to add a little bit at a
time to the gravy and you want to bring
this up to a boil now because that
instant flour doesn't come - its
thickening potential until it's brought
up to a boil once it comes up to a boil
you'll be able to gauge whether or not
your gravy is thick enough so you can
add a little
bit more if you want it to be thicker or
you could stop and you're ready to serve
our gravies come up to a boil it's nice
and thick and all you have to do now is
serve this up so here is the lumpy gravy
that we fixed just by straining and
adding a little bit more thickener and
then of course our gravy 101 which we've
made from scratch so there you have it
gravy 101 from start to finish lump-free
and if it does happen to you where you
get lumps in your gravy an easy way to
fix it
so kitchen conundrum solved enjoy your
Thanksgiving
you
